description:
Bremia lactucae is a species of oomycete, a water mold that is known to cause downy mildew disease in various lettuce (Lactuca) species. Oomycetes are fungus-like organisms that are classified as Chromista, distinct from true fungi.

Bremia lactucae is an obligate biotroph, meaning it can only grow and reproduce on living host plants. It infects the leaves of lettuce plants, forming white, fluffy fungal-like growth on the underside of the leaves. This growth contains the asexual sporangiophores and sporangia that release zoospores, the infective propagules.

The pathogen can spread rapidly in cool, humid conditions, causing significant yield losses in lettuce crops. Bremia lactucae exhibits high genetic variability, making it capable of quickly adapting to overcome plant resistance genes. Understanding the biology and life cycle of this oomycete pathogen is crucial for developing effective disease management strategies in lettuce production.
